Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: Collaborative Research: Formal Analysis of Distributed Interactions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
A crucial problem in dependability of concurrent and distributed software systems, which have become prevalent with the advances in service-oriented architecture, cloud computing, multi-core hardware, is the coordination of different components that form the whole system. In order to complete a task, components of a software system have to coordinate their executions by interacting with each other.
Message-based communication is an increasingly common interaction mechanism used in concurrent and distributed systems where components interact with each other by sending and receiving messages. The objective of the proposed research is to develop novel techniques for specification, analysis, and verification of message-based interactions.

The proposed research will develop a hierarchy of communication contract specification models and investigate analysis and verification problems for each class. Within the proposed framework the interactions among components of a software system (called peers) will be modeled as conversations describing the global sequence of messages exchanged among the peers. The proposed research will result in a toolset for analyzing communication contracts and verifying properties of conversations generated by a set of peers that follow a
given communication contract. The research will have broader impact
in at least three areas. By developing techniques for analysis and verification of message-based interactions in concurrent and distributed systems, the research will improve the dependability of software systems in a wide variety of application domains, including e-commerce, consumer applications, and telecommunications. Secondly, the research activity will help to expose graduate and undergraduate students to analysis and verification problems in concurrent and distributed systems, and message-based communication, through a variety of educational activities including courses, seminars and individual research mentoring. Finally, the research activity will help to disseminate the knowledge, techniques and tools developed for analysis and verification of communicating systems through publishing in the open literature, and making the software tools available in public domain.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SHF: Small: Collaborative Research: Formal Analysis of Distributed Interactions
http://fmg.cs.iastate.edu/project-pages/async/

The advances in Internet technologies and the new trends in computing
such as service-oriented computing, cloud computing, multi-core
hardware, have resulted in the proliferation of distributed and
concurrent software systems. The central theme in such a distributed
paradigm is that multiple components (software and hardware alike)
communicate with each other in a cooperative fashion to realize a
desired functionality and/or provide a specified service to the end
user. One of the important problems in developing such systems is to
ensure that the system, when deployed, behaves in a predictable
fashion, i.e., behaves as specified/required.  The challenge in
providing such assurance stems from the fact that identifying all
possible behavior in a distributed message-passing system is
computationally impossible, in general.  The project makes significant
inroads in this context by presenting several theoretical results that
correspond to automatically providing correctness guarantees for
certain class of distributed message-passing systems. The results are
also utilized to develop tools and technologies that show their
practical applicability in the context of service-oriented computing,
message-passing processes in operating systems (Singularity OS) and
distributed systems, in general.


Key Knowledge Gaps addressed in the Project

We address two key problems in this project. First, we have identified
the conditions under which the communicating behavior of distributed
systems can be automatically analyzed for correctness and presented
efficient methods for verifying those conditions. We have considered
these conditions and their verification in the context of different
types of communicating paradigm such as Peer-2-Peer communication with
dedicated channels for each interactions or for each message
exchanges, and communication through shared channel.

Second, we consider the problem of automatically checking whether or
not a specified interaction pattern can be implemented or realized in
practice. We have showed that if the specified patterns satisfy
certain properties, then they can be realized. We proved that these
properties can be verified efficiently. We have further investigated
automated techniques for repairing specifications that are
unrealizable such that the repaired version becomes realizable. We
characterize the repair techniques into two classes: repair by
relaxation and repair by restrictions, and discuss scenarios where the
combination of techniques from both classes may become necessary.

Project Findings

Synchronizability and realizability of message-passing asynchronous
systems modeled as communicating finite state machines were open
problems. As part of the project, we have proved that these problems
are decidable and presented efficient algorithms for checking
synchronizability and realizability conditions.  We have also
developed prototype tools and evaluated their applicability in several
case studies in the domains of service-oriented computing, distributed
software and Singularity OS.


Benefit to Science of Computing

The results obtained from our research directly impacts development of
distributed software systems both in terms of verifying desired
properties of developed software and in terms of ensuring the
implementability of software with desired properties.
